Dear Ms. Luzi:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on January 8-
January 16, 2018. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and ISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any
state where the person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
Eight personnel files were reviewed. Two out of the eight
files did not have documentation from the department that
the person was not named on central registry before
employment began.
Central registry was being completed on MiSACWIS before
employment occurred and then the agency would obtain
the documentation from the department’s central registry.
4

R 400.12309 Records Check
(1) An agency shall, upon receipt of an application, request
the department of state police to conduct both a
criminal history check and a criminal records check
through the federal bureau of investigation for
applicants. The agency shall also request the
department to conduct a criminal history check on all
persons residing in the home over 18 years of age.
Additional checks shall pertain to previous licenses and
substantiated child abuse and neglect records for all
applicants and persons residing in the home 18 years
of age or over.
Six licensed foster home files were reviewed. One out of six
files did not have a clearance completed for a person over
the age of 18.
R 400.12323 Emergency policy.
(1) An agency's emergency policy shall, at a minimum,
contain provisions for ensuring that a foster parent has
agency-approved written procedures for each of the
following emergencies:
(a) Fire.
(b) Tornado.
(c) Serious accident or injury.
Six licensed foster home files were reviewed. One out of
the six files did not have the foster parent’s complete
emergency evacuations quarterly. The file stated they did
not do them because the children were too young. The
agency policy did not dictate times when quarterly
emergency procedures did not need to be done in a
licensed foster home.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
Six foster home files were reviewed. One out of six did not have
a reevaluation completed. The evaluation should have been
completed on or around 6/7/17. It had not completed as of yet.
5

R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(a) All changes to the factual information contained in the
initial evaluation and subsequent renewal evaluations.
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the reevaluation.
(7) An agency shall notify the foster parent that a copy of the
reevaluation is available upon request.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Six foster home files were reviewed. Two out of six
reevaluations did not have changes documented in the
evaluations.
One out of six files did not have information in the report
consistent with the placement specifications. The agency
recommended four children but the home only had two beds
available.
Two out of six did not notify the foster parents that a copy of the
report was available upon request.
One out of six files did not have a reevaluation provided to the
department within 15 days of the expiration.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
6

(i) Specify the methods, the persons responsible, the time
frames for correction; methods for ensuring the safety of any
children placed in the home; how continuing compliance will be
maintained once compliance is achieved; consequences if the
corrective action plan is not completed; and what documentation
will be required to demonstrate compliance or completion.
(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the agency.
Three special investigations were reviewed. One investigation
had a corrective action plan (CAP) created. The CAP did stated
specific documents needed to be collected to determine
compliance with the CAP. These documents were not collected,
although the CAP was closed.
The CAP was only signed by one of the two foster parents on
the license. The CAP needs to be signed by all licensees.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing the
placement of a child in the home.
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept the
foster child.
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement by
the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
Three borrowed bed files were reviewed.
One out of three files did not have prior approval before
placement. POS occurred on 7/5/17 and approval was
documented 7/13/17.
One out of three files did not have the documentation that the
foster parent was willing to accept the foster child before
placement.
Three out of three files did not have endorsement of the initial or
current reevaluations before placement of the child.
7

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
(d) Notify all social service workers who have children placed in
the home that a special evaluation has been initiated.
Three foster care files were reviewed. Three special
investigations were reviewed.
One out of three special investigations did not have an
investigation record submitted within 5 days of the intake.
The intake was on 8/21/17 and the investigation record was
sent on 8/29/17.
Two out of three special investigations did not document that
the social service workers with children placed were notified of
the special investigation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(a) The date the information was received.
One out of three special investigations did not have the report
completed within 15 days of completion of the investigation. The
investigation was completed on 9/5/17 and the report was
completed on 9/26/17.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
8

(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
Three out of three special investigations did not provide the
foster parent with the report within 10 days of the report being
completed.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
Three out of three special investigations did not inform the foster
parent that they could have their written response included as
an attachment.
R 400.12404 Placement
(7) An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(a) All of the following child characteristics:
(i) Gender.
(ii) Race.
(iii) Height and weight.
(iv) Eye color and hair color.
(v) Identifying marks.
(vi) Religious preference.
(vii) School status, including grade, last school attended, and
educational program.
(b) Name, known addresses, and marital status of the child’s
parents or legal guardian, if any.
(c) Names, ages, and known addresses of any siblings.
(d) Known names, addresses, and dates of any previous out-of-
home placements.
(e) The date that the agency received the child for placement.
(f) The child’s legal status and the agency’s legal right to provide
care.
(g) Documentation of the child’s placement preparation.
(i) Documentation that American Indian ancestry was assessed.
Eight foster care files were reviewed.
9

Three out of eight foster care files did not have the gender, race,
height and weight, eye color and hair color of the child placed in
the file within 7 days of placement.
Five out of eight files did not have the child’s identifying marks in
the file within 7 days of placement.
Four out of eight files did not have the child’s religious
preference in the file within 7 calendar days of placement.
Three out of eight did not have the child’s school status in the
file within 7 days of placement.
Four out of eight files did not have the name of the parents in
the child’s file within 7 days of placement.
Six out of eight files did not have the name of the child’s siblings
in the file within 7 days of placement.
Four out of eight files did not have the previous out of home
placements in the file within 7 days of placement.
Three out of eight files did not have the date the agency
received the child in the child’s file within 7 days of placement.
Three out of eight files did not have the legal status of the child
in the child’s file within 7 days of placement.
Four out of eight files did not have the child’s placement
preparation in the child’s file within 7 days of placement.
Four out of eight files did not have the American Indian ancestry
in the child’s file within 7 days of placement.
10

R 400.12405 Change of Placement
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out of the eight foster
care files had a change in placement.
Two out of two files did not have the information consistent with
R 400.12417 in the file before the change of placement
occurred.
R 400.12418 Development of Service Plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service
plan must be completed within 30 calendar days of the
change in agency responsibility if no other plan is done
within 30 days. The plan shall address why the agency
responsibility changed and whether there are any
modifications to existing service plans.
Seventeen service plans were reviewed. Fourteen service plans
were reviewed that had to be completed within 120 calendar
days of initial placement and 90 calendar days thereafter.
Four out of the fourteen were not completed in the specified
time frame. One report was due on 10/29/17 and was
completed on 10/30/17. One report was due on 5/30/17 and
was completed on 6/20/17. One report was due on 8/28/17 and
was completed on 8/31/17. One report was due on 11/26/17
and was completed on 11/28/17.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Three out of the eight did
not have a report completed within 30 days of the agency
change in responsibility.
11

R 400.12420 Updated Service Plans
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(b) Confirmation that the child’s current foster home
continues to appropriately meet the placement needs of the
child.
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from the
child, the child’s parents or legal guardian, foster parents,
referring agency, and others, unless the agency documents
why any of these entities cannot be involved.
(d) Assessment of progress in achieving the permanency
goal for the child.
(e) A plan which includes any changes made since the
previous plan and which has the content specified in R
400.12419.
Eight foster care files were reviewed.
One out of eight foster care files did not confirm that the child’s
placement continued to be appropriate.
Three out of eight foster care files did not provide a summary of
pertinent information since the last service plan.
One out of eight foster care files did not have an assessment of
progress in achieving permanency.
Four out of eight foster care files did not have a plan which
includes changes since the previous plan.
R 400.12604 Orientation and Application
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application is
provided.
Six adoption files were reviewed.
12

One out of six files did not document that orientation was
completed before the application was provided.
13

ISEP 6.33(c) Page 28 Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the caseworker’s supervisor,
the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren)
or both are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall include
an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and shall identify any follow-up
actions to be taken to secure their participation in services.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Seventeen service plans were reviewed. One
out of seventeen service plans did not have a parent signature on it.
ISEP 6.30 Page 27 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned worker to review the
status and progress of each case on the worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall
review and approve each service plan. The plan can be approved only after the
supervisor has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the monthly
meeting.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Seventeen service plans were reviewed. One
out of seventeen supervision meetings did not take place before the service plan
was due.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
15

DHHS Policy FOM 801 Page 11-13 Medical Passports
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must maintain a medical
passport containing all items listed in MCL 722.954c.
The medical passport is generated from MiSACWIS. The health information
entered into the MiSACWIS Health Profile section, such as the child's
appointments, medications, and so forth, populates the corresponding section
of the medical passport. The health screens within the MiSACWIS Health Profile
section must be updated quarterly to ensure the child's current health
information is up-to-date and accurate.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out of eight files did not have the medical
passport provided to the foster parent.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 Page 16-17 Required Content of Medical Passport
Medical Passport (DHHS-221) must contain documentation of the following
items:
All health information that has been entered into the MiSACWIS Health Profile
section is downloaded into the child's medical passport upon generating the
report.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Seven out of the eight foster care files did not
have all health information in the document.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C Page 2 Required Participation in Development -
Foster Parent / Caregiver
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver to meet the
specific individual needs of the child placed in their home are included in the
PATP. The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP process. The
foster parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the foster
parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the activities required to meet the
needs of the child in their care.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Seventeen service plans were reviewed. One
out of seventeen service plans did not have the foster parent’s signature on it.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Page 12 CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH
SUPERVISOR (SUPERVISION)
The caseworker must meet with his/her supervisor at least monthly for case
consultation on every active case.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight foster care files showed one
supervision missing.

16

placement resources, current placement, residential care, and permanent

DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - Page 5 - CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN OUT-
OF-HOME PLACEMENT: The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face

placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face contact with the child

STANDARDS

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
DHHS Policy 722-06I – page 3-4 – Parenting time Supervision: Did the caseworker
personally observe parenting time at least once a month
Parenting visits need to be observed once a month from the caseworker. When writing
case notes pertaining to these visits, the agency will need to document that the case
worker supervised the visit. Without the case note including they observed the parenting
time, one would not know if they actually did.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and assessment of all

18

(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as determined by observation of,

A reevaluation was completed where interviews were not completed with the child, only
observations. When writing the report, anytime a person is unable to be interviewed, the
writer needs to state they attempted to interview the individual, but was unsuccessful
and provide the reason why.

VII. DCWL Analyst Findings:
One foster family did not receive monthly case manager visits for the months of
February, March, and April 2017.
Response: Foster home visits are documented as occurring on 2/6/17 @ 9 pm
(scheduled), 3/27/17 @ 7:30 (unannounced), 4/12/17 @ 3:45 pm (scheduled).
The following concerns were noted for the same foster case:
The biological dad states he:
 was not given the opportunity to give input into the service plan and therefore
has not signed the service plan.
 has not been invited to attend a Family Team Meeting
 does not feel the agency is supportive of his mental health needs.
 has not had monthly contact with the assigned case manager.
 has not had quarterly in home visits by the assigned case manager.
 is offered weekly parenting time at DHHS. He has mental health issues that
won’t allow him to spend one hour in a small room. The case manager won’t
accommodate his needs so that he can participate in visits with his children.
 is not involved in medical decisions for one of his children. He disagrees with the
medications being given to his son.
 cannot participate in medical or educational appointments for 2 of his children in
out of county placement. Transportation is a barrier.
 is not notified of medical or educational appointments for his children.
 was not notified of the placement of his children into foster care timely.
Response: He has been a non-participating member since the onset of the case.
He has never attended a Court hearing or FTM. He does not have a stable
residence; efforts were made to visit him at various addresses, but he was no
longer living at any of them. The Court did order the birth mother to provide an
address for him at one point during the case. He did attend the children’s initial
medical appointment, as well as some sporadic parenting time appointments in
the beginning of the case. He has documented mental health concerns (he is
diagnosed with Bipolar disorder and Schizophrenia), as well as a history of
domestic violence and threatening workers. There is a “Safety Hazard” in the
MiSACWIS system regarding him given his explosive nature and the fact that he
stated he is not taking his prescribed psychotropic medication. Given this safety
20

issue, his parenting time must be held at DHHS to protect the children as well as
the assigned worker. Monthly contacts are made with him regarding his
involvement with the case plan as well as the parenting time schedule. His
responses to these contacts is argumentative, threatening, and inappropriate. He
is encouraged to contact his court appointed attorney and appear at Court
hearings. His Parent Agency Treatment Plan is mailed to the last known address
we have for him. Workers have attempted to complete home visits at his last
known address, but have been unsuccessful (documented in MiSACWIS
including but not limited to 4/13/17 & 6/21/17). It should be noted that he was also
not involved with case planning the first time his children were in foster care in
2012-2013.
The biological mother states she:
 is not involved in educational decisions for 2 of her children due to an out of
county placement. Transportation is a barrier.
 is concerned that the staff turnover has impacted the length of the case.
Response: Biological mother was informed of all school meetings and medical
appointments for the children; arrangements were made to allow her to
participate in these events via telephone if she was unable to attend in person.
The worker changes did not affect the length of the case at all; in fact it was
beneficial to the case, as each worker provided a “new set of eyes” and made
observations regarding the home conditions
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
